instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Tested with genuine 85W charger.
Cant find any liquid on board but trackpad is damaged by liquid which is powered by <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_TPAD</SIGNAL> and I think thats why 5V rail is missing.

Got light on charger and was checking list of power rails and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is missing.
There is no short to ground when there is no power on the board, but when charger is connected got short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>.

Don?t know much about 5V / 3.3V Power Supply but thats what I got.

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>/16 @12.62V
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>/3 @2.001V

L7260 @3.33V on both sides
L7220 @0.0V on both sides

<TRANSISTOR>Q7210</TRANSISTOR>/3 @3.40V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7210</TRANSISTOR>/5 @0.0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> @0.0V

Thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Are you shorting the power pads to try and turn it on? If so, what is your resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
"when charger is connected got short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>"
You are not the first, but I recommend you STOP to check continuity on a powered board!!!

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal and see if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at least.
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/1153-johnb8812"]JohnB8812[/URL][/B]
When shorting power pads nothing happen.
Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.030 kOhm


[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/682-2informaticos"]2informaticos[/URL][/B]
"You are not the first, but I recommend you STOP to check continuity on a powered board!!!"
Thanks, will not doing that anymore :)

"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal and see if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at least."
No pulse.

SMC bypass - still dead

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
"Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.030 kOhm"
Too low, MCP is dead almost sure.
You must get more than 30K there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Yeah 3Kohms is too low dead MCP waste of time
